ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: we haven't gone on any field trips yet, so I could not comment on that

I thought the majority of the best content was rushed into the first half of the semester (pre-midterm) and could have been spaced better. the second half felt repetetive, and i wished that we could have gone into more depth on some of the topics covered quickly during the first half (fire effects, etc)

The first half of the course was excellent. Full of very relevant information. It seemed to sort of taper off after the midterm. Though both the TA and the professor were responsive to student interest.

I couldn't go to the prescribed fire due to a scheduling conflict.I think the readings should be better integrated into the classes. The discussion sections were held twice a semester and that was the main way the readings were integrated into the class. That's not enough from my experience.I think the Science part of the class is much stronger than the Policy part of the class. Ann is a scientist and her strength is on the science side. Strengthening the policy part of the class would include giving students better analytical tools for assessing policy and policy making. There's not enough rigor in the presentation of the history, nor conceptual richness in discussing how policy is made.
The readings were often not posted until the night before class or even the day of. This made it very difficult to plan ahead and get the reading completed.
#9: I think there ought to be field trips for this class and some kind of lab in which we can engage in the incident command system process.

This is a key class - fire is an enormously important component of forest management. The instructor was very much willing to incorporate student interests into the curriculum, which was appreciated. The prescribed burn was hugely important for a learning experience and it would have been great to have another field trip - to the CT DEP fire fighting division, or other active operation, or to see a site burned at varying times over the years.
the open structure. the fire topics really lend themselves to discussion, so student discussion is important

This is the only class where MFs can get any real exposure to USFS Forest policy in this country. I am glad I took it as a result of this exposure but that seems odd to have to take a fire class to gain that.
Ann's experience in the Forest Service and work around fire in the interior West are the strengths of the class.
- Brings out the significance of technical scientific knowledge about fire.- Great real-life examples- Interactive discussions
I enjoyed the presentations from FES students that had experience in fire (Cam Moore, Jason Lawhon, Charlie Mumford). They knew a lot about the subject and really added to the class.
The western focus.

A lot of the direction of the course was left in the hands of the student. There is no over-arching answers to questions of fire policy. A basic understanding of fire science was covered in the first half of the course, and then the second half of course allowed students to explore, discuss and engage in policy topics and questions. The professor provided guidance and experience, but the students were encouraged to explore and make the learning our own. Very effective.
The special guests and hearing their personal insight.
The instructor's flexibility, passion and knowledge about the subject. Good readings and involvement of students in the class.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: the syllabus and course plan could be clear. similarly, the exam itself could have been clearer.
Pace of the semester and covering material
Better structure and building of the material presented.
See above (policy).
More examples from the tropics
Structure. The first half was well structured, but after that it sort of went by the wayside.
Timely posting of readings, slightly more structure.

The student discussions were fruitful. Continued efforts to encourage these and facilitate such exchanges would be highly valuable. The guest lectures were wonderful, and I understand scheduling is also problematic, but the course would benefit from grouping these immediately following the fire science/behavior lectures so that the last several weeks of the course could be all student discussions regarding all we have been exposed to.

The class should involve some written assignments beyond the final paper - a short evaluation of a wildfire, or prescribed burn composed from literature, problem sets involving scenarios, ICS and fuel calculations, or a computer model that helped understand the dynamics of wind and fire behavior.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: TA very good at maintaining engagement and closing loop between prof and class. Both could have been more organized on changes to the syllabus.
See first comment
Fine.
Both Instructor and TA where readily available to help with technical and logistics-related problems. Good team!
They were available when I approached them.
The instructor and TA were both very knowledge and eager to engage with students. The instructor and TA worked in tandem well and provided an effective learning environment.
They were always available and ready to help in class or outside of class time.
Excellent - both always available when needed and quick to reply.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: fire is an important disturbance on the environment. I think it is essential for any one doing land management
Fire ecology is essential part of forestry.
I'm an MF so fire is critical to my program.

This course fit well into my post-graduate conservation work life. I have worked in communities where fire is a prominent feature in the dry season. The course has given me some useful tools to design better management programs.
My interest lies in western conservation and having a course offering like this at FES is very beneficial to my career development.

I think it's a very important class in the FES curriculum and hope it keeps its annual slot. For me, it was a fundamental forest science class that really has helped me grasp the practical challenges of forest management through one important facet.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: to prepare myself for managing fire adapted landscapes in my professional career
TO understand fire ecology and behavior
My advisor, Mark, said I needed to.
To gain a systematic knowledge of fire science and ecology
I intend to live and work in communities that are affected by wildland fire. I figured I should know a little bit of the science and policy surrounding the topic.
See above.

I am focusing on land conservation applications at large scales. I am undecided if I will focus in New England or the Rocky Mountain west. I took this class as an introduction to the issue of fire management and policy, which will be critical to understand if I find myself working in the west. It served the intended purpose very well.
I will be working in forestry in the West, and fire plays a big role in forest management there. I just like fire and want to learn about it.
I had always intended to - it'sa basic class for this field.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes
Mostly.
Yes.
I was a little disappointed that the prescribed burn was so late in the semester, it would have been more enjoyable if it was incorporated earlier (weather and permits aside).
Yes, the course introduced me to the topic, providing me a working knowledge of fire science and policy in the United States.

I was hoping to do a burn. Although we did have the chance to do a burn, it was during finals. The class surpassed my expectations with regard to guest speakers. I didn't expect to learn so much from their insight. I also enjoyed finding out how our school's history ties in with the history of the Forest Service.

Yes and no - I learned what I needed to learn but I wish I would have left with a better grasp on basic fire and climate interactions which I am still hazy about. Written assignments or problem sets would have been helpful. Or a modeling exercise online.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
Considerably
I suppose. I know more about fire. The class could be a little more intensive.

I have a working knowledge of fire science and policy/management issues. Importantly, I have come to grasp that there is no "right" way to pursue fire management. The course fulfilled my expectations and forced me to think critically about how and what management should be pursued.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I think we could have done nice case studies in groups about particular fires. Or developing fire plans in specific regions.
It was a last-minute effort but helpful to make me focus on the assignment (being accountable to others). We prepared a discussion section.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: the course has a very low work load, but you should try to participate fully in the discussions
Please take the course. Fire is an integral part of ecology and the environment
You get out of it what you bring into it. This is a seminar style course- if you don't take time picking good articles to discuss, the discussions will reflect that.

Start the paper early. It is a wonderful opportunity to dig deeply into the a topic of interest to you and apply what you have learned through the class. Also, make sure you get to the prescribed burn.

Read through the readings and formulate questions for the instructor. Find other readings to complement what you're learning in class. This class will help you understand basics of fire science and policy, but you won't become well-versed in it unless you work on the ground in fire.
Talk to the instructor and TA early about how to include your interests in the class.
